# General context {background-image="illustrations/presentation/sectionbg.png" background-size="cover"}

## Livestock's part in the global food security challenge

- Food demand is expected to increase between **30%** and **62%** by 2050 [@vandijkMetaanalysisProjectedGlobal2021].
- Failure of the Green Revolution to address global food security [@cassidyRedefiningAgriculturalYields2013; @garibaldiFarmingApproachesGreater2017].
- Globalised grain-feed systems:
  - decline and degradation of global grassland areas [@bardgettCombattingGlobalGrassland2021];
  - large environmental externalities [@cunninghamCloseYieldgapSaving2013; @hongGlobalRegionalDrivers2021].

## {.center}

![@bardgettCombattingGlobalGrassland2021](illustrations/presentation/bardgettCombattingGlobalGrassland2021.png)

## Beyond the productivist perspective

**Agricultural multifunctionality**: synergy between food security, the integrity of ecosystems and human well-being [@ipbesThematicAssessmentReport2024].

:::{.notes}
- **Ecosystem services**: ecological characteristics, functions or processes used for the economic valuation of ecosystem contributions to human well-being [@costanzaTwentyYearsEcosystem2017; @haines-youngCommonInternationalClassification2018].
- **Multifunctionality**: capacity of agricultural systems to ensure the delivery of multiple ecosystem services [@oecdMultifunctionalityAnalyticalFramework2001].
:::

![@kremenLandscapesThatWork2018](illustrations/presentation/kremenLandscapesThatWork2018A.png){width="90%" style="margin:40px"}

## Biodiversity x ecosystem services

![@hectorBiodiversityEcosystemMultifunctionality2007](illustrations/presentation/hectorBiodiversityEcosystemMultifunctionality2007.webp)

:::{.notes}
- how biodiversity relates to these bundles ?
- Expected synergies: underlying ecosystem processes affected by different sets of species [@hectorBiodiversityEcosystemMultifunctionality2007; @soliveresBiodiversityMultipleTrophic2016].
:::

## Synergies and trade-offs {.center}

![@leprovostSupplyMultipleEcosystem2022](illustrations/presentation/leprovostAdapted.png)

:::{.notes}
- Highly context-dependent in relation to the local environment and the type of management
- If the aim is to favour practices that support biodiversity and maximise synergies without too much trade-offs for productivity
- then we need policy-oriented research to investigate synergies and trade-offs under different farming models and across multiple ecosystems and sociocultural backgrounds [@egliWinnersLosersNational2018; @rockstromSustainableIntensificationAgriculture2017].
:::

# Ecological study in the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve {background-image="illustrations/presentation/sectionbg.png" background-size="cover"}

## Aim of the thesis {.center}

This PhD thesis aims to **explore how grazing-dependent habitats support biodiversity and ecosystem service delivery** in the agroecological landscape of the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve.
<!-- - Our work was based on observational studies of **42 semi-natural grasslands and heathlands**, distributed across a west-east gradient in the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve. -->

## (Q2.1) Management: livestock type

+---------------------------------------------------------------------+--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Results                                                             | Interpretation                                                                                         | 
+:====================================================================+:=======================================================================================================+
| - cattle-grazed fields with higher Poaceae cover                    | - may indicate higher trampling disturbance &/or more intensive management in cattle-grazed fields     | 
| - weak association between sheep grazing & cryptogam cover          |                                                                                                        |
+---------------------------------------------------------------------+--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
| - no effect on plant diversity or dominant plant species            | - no evidence of greater forage selectivity by smaller livestock                                       |
| - no direct effect on dominant dung-associated beetle families      | - no evidence of greater dung supply in cattle-grazed fields                                           |
+---------------------------------------------------------------------+--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
| - potential indirect link with dominant grass and forb species      | - can indicate top-down or bottom-up interactions                                                      |
+---------------------------------------------------------------------+--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+


## (Q2.2) Management: prescribed burning

+---------------------------------------------------------------------+--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Results                                                             | Interpretation                                                                                         | 
+:====================================================================+:=======================================================================================================+
| - lower alpha diversity on burnt patches                            | - no evidence of positive effect of burning on patch diversity                                         |
| - community divergence according to moisture & vegetation cover     | - niche diversification favouring the activity of specialists                                          |
+---------------------------------------------------------------------+--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
| - higher between-site divergence in coastal sites                   | - burning contribute to heathland heterogeneity at regional scale                                      |
+---------------------------------------------------------------------+--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+

## Limitations of our study design {visibility="hidden"}

- the scale, whether for capturing environmental heterogeneity (e.g. fjord topography) or management-driven heterogeneity (e.g. rotational management)
- the biological indicators: especially arthropods

:::{.notes}
- Environmental heterogeneity
- Livestock-driven heterogeneity at the field scale
- Management-driven heterogeneity at the landscape scale
- Selection of biological indicators
:::

## Optimisation methodological approach

- **Spatially-explicit analyses**: greater robustness to disentangle the influences underlying environmental gradients.
- **Farm-scale approaches**: better consideration of management rotational dynamic.
- **High resolution indicators**: to address current knowledge gaps on arthropods and soil fauna.
- **Transdisciplinary approaches**: better consideration of farmers' roles and facilitation policy-making.

# Conclusion {background-image="illustrations/presentation/sectionbg.png" background-size="cover"}

## {.center}

- TAKE-HOME:
  - land use in the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve still **largely determined by the environment** of the fjord region.
  - **biological and functional complementarity** of semi-natural grasslands and heathlands.
  - **no indication of detrimental effects** of livestock type or prescribed burning on plant and animal communities.
- PERSPECTIVES:
  - win-win strategies promoting **biodiversity and multifunctionality** are already within our reach.
  - need more research efforts on already existing models of small-scale and diversified farming.

## The Intermediate Disturbance Hypothesis {visibility="uncounted"}

![Plant diversity of grassland communities in relation to grazing intensity along gradients of moisture and grazing evolutionary history, from @milchunasGeneralizedModelEffects1988](illustrations/presentation/milchunasGeneralizedModelEffects1988.png){#fig-milchunas}

:::{.notes}
- At moderate intensity, grazing pressure is expected to be strong enough to locally overcome the competition for light, but not so excessive as to homogenise the sward with grazing-tolerant species [@koernerChangeDominanceDetermines2018; @olffEffectsHerbivoresGrassland1998].
- This intermediate stage of highest spatial heterogeneity should result in a biodiversity optimum, by favouring the coexistence of multiple life strategies and ecological niches for plant and animal communities [@ceraboliniWhyAreMany2016; @steinEnvironmentalHeterogeneityUniversal2014].
:::

:::{.notes}
- In nutrient-poor habitats, the prevalence of stress-tolerance strategies usually limits plant growth rate and reproductive capacities [@diazGlobalSpectrumPlant2016; @pierceLeafEconomicsSpectrum2007], increasing the vulnerability of communities to ruderal and fast-growing species [@pakemanConsistencyPlantSpecies2004; @teuberLivestockGrazingIntermountain2013].
- The relationship between grazing and biodiversity thus depends on both the ecosystem capacity to tolerate disturbance [@piipponenGlobalTrendsGrassland2022] and the management adaptability to abiotic constraints [@plieningerTraditionalLanduseNature2006; @torokGrazingEuropeanOpen2016].
:::

## The Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve {visibility="uncounted"}

- **UNESCO's Man and the Biosphere Programme (MAB)**: aims to "improve human livelihoods, and the equitable sharing of benefits, and to safeguard natural and managed ecosystems, promoting innovative approaches to economic development that are socially and culturally appropriate and environmentally sustainable" [@unescoManBiosphereProgramme2025].
- **Biosphere Reserves**: model areas for experimenting innovative pathways for sustainable development [@barracloughGlobalKnowledgeAction2023; @unescoNewRoadmapMan2017].
- World Network of Biosphere Reserves: 784 sites across 142 countries for a total population of 300 million people [@unescoManBiosphereProgramme2025].

## Agriculture history in Western Norway {visibility="uncounted"}

- Early Neolithic: introduction of burning and domestic grazing [@hjelleHesitantHuntersReview2006; @prosch-danielsenPalaeoecologicalInvestigationsReconstruction2000].
- **Traditional infield-outfield system**: mixed crop-livestock system, involving energy transfers from grazed outfields (*utmark*) to cultivated infields (*innmark*).
- Post-WW2 rationalisation: livestock moved to the infields to address market demands, leading to enlargement and intensification of fertile fields and abandonment of remote and nutrient-poor areas [@jonesLandtenureLandscapeChange1988].
- Smaller holdings (under 10 ha) most impacted: dropped from representing 90% of total Norwegian farms in 1949 to 53% in 1995 [@fjellstadPatternsChangeTwo1999].

## Farm management {visibility="uncounted"}

- Farmer interviews: 39 interviews between October 2021 and January 2022, successively led by Linn Voldstad and Silje Östman.
- Information on management practices:
  - the livestock breed;
  - the number of adult and young animals (**paper III**);
  - the surface area of the field we visited (**paper III**);
  - the occupation period of the field by livestock (**paper III**);
  - the grazing history including current and former livestock as well as past land use;
  - the type, frequency and intensity of additional management, e.g. fertilisation, mulching and burning.

+--------------------+-------------------+-------------------+------------------+-----------------+-------------+

+--------------------+-------------------+-------------------+------------------+-----------------+-------------+
